laws.summary: North Dakota does not have a statewide law prohibiting employers from asking about salary history.
requirements: Employers may legally ask about prior salary
Use of salary history may create discrimination risk under federal law
Best practice is to avoid salary history inquiries
laws.notes: While legal in ND, many employers avoid salary history questions to reduce risk under Title VII and Equal Pay Act.

laws.summary: North Dakota does not require employers to disclose pay ranges in job postings or offer letters.
laws.statute_citation: No current statute mandating pay transparency
requirements: Pay range disclosure is not legally required
Employers may voluntarily include compensation information
Federal equal pay and anti-discrimination laws still apply
laws.notes: Future legislation may change this area; monitoring recommended.

laws.summary: Non-compete agreements are largely prohibited in North Dakota, with limited statutory exceptions.
requirements: Contracts restraining lawful profession, trade, or business are void
Limited exceptions exist for sale of business goodwill
Limited exceptions exist for dissolution of partnership
Employment-related non-competes are generally unenforceable
Non-solicitation clauses may also be unenforceable if overly restrictive
laws.notes: North Dakota is one of the most restrictive states regarding non-compete enforcement, similar to California.

laws.summary: North Dakota does not have a statewide ban-the-box law for private employers, but federal FCRA requirements apply when using background check vendors.
requirements: Written consent required before third-party background checks
Must provide pre-adverse action notice before taking negative action
Must provide copy of report and summary of rights
Must issue adverse action notice if decision is finalized
Criminal history use must be non-discriminatory
laws.notes: Applies whenever a consumer reporting agency is used.

laws.summary: North Dakota does not mandate paid sick leave statewide but protects certain civic leave rights.
requirements: Employees must be allowed leave for jury duty
Employers cannot penalize employees for jury service
Employees may take time off to vote if necessary
No statewide paid sick leave requirement
laws.notes: Offer letters should not conflict with statutory civic leave protections.

laws.summary: North Dakota allows workplace drug testing and does not provide employment protections for recreational cannabis use.
requirements: Employers may maintain drug-free workplace policies
Drug testing policies should be applied consistently
Cannabis remains illegal for recreational use under state law
Employers may discipline based on positive drug tests
laws.notes: North Dakota is employer-friendly regarding drug testing policies.

laws.summary: Arbitration agreements are generally enforceable in North Dakota if they meet fairness and contract law requirements.
laws.statute_citation: Federal Arbitration Act; North Dakota contract law
requirements: Agreement must be voluntary and clear
Must not be unconscionable
Must provide reasonable notice
Courts may invalidate one-sided clauses

laws.summary: North Dakota is an at-will employment state, subject to statutory and public policy exceptions.
requirements: Employment is presumed at-will unless contract provides otherwise
Cannot terminate for discriminatory reasons
Cannot terminate for retaliation
Public policy exceptions apply
Employee handbooks may create implied obligations
laws.notes: Clear at-will language in offer letters is recommended.

laws.summary: North Dakota law prohibits discrimination in employment based on protected characteristics.
laws.statute_citation: North Dakota Human Rights Act (N.D. Cent. Code § 14-02.4-01 et seq.)
requirements: Cannot discriminate based on race, color, religion, sex, national origin
Cannot discriminate based on age (40+)
Cannot discriminate based on disability
Harassment is prohibited
Retaliation for protected activity is prohibited
laws.notes: Offer letters should avoid language implying bias or exclusion.

data_quality.sources: North Dakota Department of Labor, North Dakota Century Code, North Dakota Human Rights Commission, official state guidance
data_quality.coverage_completeness: comprehensive for offer-letter and hiring compliance

additional_notes.general_guidance: North Dakota is highly restrictive on non-competes but otherwise relatively employer-friendly in hiring compliance.
enforcement_agencies: North Dakota Department of Labor and Human Rights
recent_developments: Continued strict statutory ban on most non-competes
No statewide pay transparency law enacted as of 2026
No statewide paid sick leave mandate
Ongoing federal enforcement for background checks and discrimination
